sen.j: 神功皇后（じんぐうこうごう、成務天皇40年（170年） - 神功69年4月17日 (旧暦)（269年6月3日））は、仲哀天皇の皇后。
sen.e: Empress Jingu (170-June 3, 269 (old calendar)) was a wife of Emperor Chuai.
Empress Jingu (A.D. 170 - June 3, A.D. 269) was a wife of Emperor Chuai.
sen.cmt: 年号の表現を見直し神功69年4月17日は変換できませんでしたので、原文のままにしました。
sen.e: Empress Jingu (A.D. 170 - June 3, A.D. 269) was a wife of Emperor Chuai.

sen.j: 『紀』では気長足姫尊（おきながたらしひめのみこと）・『記』では息長帯比売命（おきながたらしひめのみこと）・大帯比売命（おおたらしひめのみこと）・大足姫命皇后。
sen.e: In "Nihonshoki"(Chronicles of Japan), she is called Okinagatarashihime no Mikoto, while in "Kojiki"(The Records of Ancient Matters), she is called Okinagatarashi-hime-no-mikoto or Otarashihime no mikoto or Empress Otarashihimenomikoto.

In "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), she is called Okinagatarashihime no Mikoto, while in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters), she is called Okinagatarashi-hime-no-mikoto, Otarashihime no mikoto or Empress Otarashihimenomikoto.
sen.cmt: Okinagatarashi-hime-no-mikoto or Otarashihime no mikoto or Empress Otarashihimenomikoto を Okinagatarashi-hime-no-mikoto, Otarashihime no mikoto or Empress Otarashihimenomikoto に変更
sen.e: In "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan), she is called Okinagatarashihime no Mikoto, while in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters), she is called Okinagatarashi-hime-no-mikoto, Otarashihime no mikoto or Empress Otarashihimenomikoto.

sen.j: 父は開化天皇玄孫・息長宿禰王（おきながのすくねのみこ）で、母はアメノヒボコ裔・葛城高顙媛（かずらきのたかぬかひめ）。
sen.e: Her father was Okinaga no sukune no miko, who was a great-great-grandson of Emperor Kaika, and her mother was Princess Kazuraginotakanuka, the descendant of Amenohiboko.
Her father was Okinaga no sukune no miko, who was a great-great-grandson of Emperor Kaika, and her mother was Princess Kazuraginotakanuka, the descendant of Amenohiboko.
Her father was Okinaga no sukune no miko, who was a great-great-grandson of Emperor Kaika, and her mother was Princess Kazuraginotakanuka, the descendant of Amenohiboko.

sen.j: 彦坐王の4世孫、応神天皇の母。
sen.e: She was also a 4世孫 of Hikoimasu no miko and mother of Emperor Ojin.
She was also a 4世孫 of Hikoimasu no miko and mother of Emperor Ojin.
She was also a 4世孫 of Hikoimasu no miko and mother of Emperor Ojin.

tit.cmt: 事績の間違えと思われます。

sen.j: 日本書紀などによれば、201年から269年まで政事を執りおこなった。
sen.e: According to "Nihonshoki" and other history books, Empress Jingu conducted political affairs from 201 to 269.
According to Nihonshoki and other history books, Empress Jingu conducted political affairs from 201 to 269.
According to Nihonshoki and other history books, Empress Jingu conducted political affairs from 201 to 269.

sen.j: 夫の仲哀天皇の急死（200年）後、住吉大神の神託により、お腹に子供（のちの応神天皇）を妊娠したまま海を渡って朝鮮半島に出兵して新羅の国を攻めた。
sen.e: After a sudden death of Emperor Chuai (in 200), although she was pregnant with the future emperor (later Emperor Ojin), she crossed the ocean and sent troops to Korean Peninsula to attack Silla by the oracle of Sumiyoshi Okami (the great gods of Sumiyoshi).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: After a sudden death of Emperor Chuai (in 200), although she was pregnant with the future emperor (later Emperor Ojin), she crossed the ocean and sent troops to Korean Peninsula to attack Silla by the oracle of Sumiyoshi Okami (the great gods of Sumiyoshi).

After a sudden death of Emperor Chuai (in 200), although she was pregnant with the future emperor (later Emperor Ojin), she crossed the ocean and sent troops to Korean Peninsula to attack Silla by the oracle of Sumiyoshi Okami (the great gods of Sumiyoshi).

sen.j: 新羅は戦わずして降服して朝貢を誓い、高句麗・百済も朝貢を約したという（三韓征伐）。
sen.e: Silla promised to pay tribute to the Court without fighting, and Goguryeo and Paekche also promised bringing tributes ("Sankan Seibatsu" (The Conquest of the Three Korean Kingdoms)).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Silla promised to pay tribute to the Court without fighting, and Goguryeo and Paekche also promised bringing tributes ("Sankan Seibatsu" (The Conquest of the Three Korean Kingdoms)).
Silla promised to pay tribute to the Court without fighting, and Goguryeo and Paekche also promised bringing tributes ("Sankan Seibatsu" (The Conquest of the Three Korean Kingdoms)).

sen.j: 渡海の際は、お腹に月延石や鎮懐石と呼ばれる石をあててさらしを巻き、冷やすことによって出産を遅らせたとされる。
sen.e: It is said that when she crossed the ocean, she tied stones called Tsukinobe ishi and Chinkai seki around her abdomen with bleached cotton to delay the birth of her child by cooling her abdomen.
It is said that when she crossed the ocean, she tied stones called Tsukinobe ishi and Chinkai seki around her abdomen with bleached cotton to delay the birth of her child by cooling her abdomen.
It is said that when she crossed the ocean, she tied stones called Tsukinobe ishi and Chinkai seki around her abdomen with bleached cotton to delay the birth of her child by cooling her abdomen.

sen.j: 月延石は三つあったとされ、それぞれ長崎県壱岐市及び京都市の月読神社と福岡県二丈町の鎮懐石八幡宮に奉納されたと言われている。
sen.e: It is said that there were three Tsukinobe ishi (Tsukinobe stone), and each of them were dedicated to Tsukiyomi-jinja Shrine in Iki City, Nagasaki Prefecture and Kyoto City, and Chinkai seki Hachiman-gu Shrine in Nijo machi, Fukuoak Prefecture, respectively.

It is said that there were three Tsukinobe ishi (Tsukinobe stone), and each of them was dedicated to Tsukiyomi-jinja Shrine in Iki City, Nagasaki Prefecture and Kyoto City, and Chinkai seki Hachiman-gu Shrine in Nijo machi, Fukuoak Prefecture, respectively.
sen.cmt: wereを wasに変更(主語はeachなので）
sen.e: It is said that there were three Tsukinobe ishi (Tsukinobe stone), and each of them was dedicated to Tsukiyomi-jinja Shrine in Iki City, Nagasaki Prefecture and Kyoto City, and Chinkai seki Hachiman-gu Shrine in Nijo machi, Fukuoak Prefecture, respectively.

sen.j: その帰路、筑紫の宇美町で応神天皇を出産し、志免町でお紙目を代えたと伝えられている。
sen.e: It has been reported that she gave birth to Emperor Ojin in Chikushi on her return home, and changed diapers in Shime cho.
It has been reported that she gave birth to Emperor Ojin in Chikushi on her return home, and changed diapers in Shime cho.
It has been reported that she gave birth to Emperor Ojin in Chikushi on her return home, and changed diapers in Shime cho.

sen.j: 他にも壱岐市の壱岐湯ノ本温泉で産湯をつかわせたなど、九州北部に数々の伝承が残っており、九州北部に縁の深い人物であったと推測される。
sen.e: In addition, there are many traditions concerning Empress Jingu in northern part of Kyushu such as bathing her newborn baby at Ikiyunomoto-Onsen Hot Spring in Iki City, therefore, it is considered that she had strong associations with this area.

In addition, there are many traditions concerning Empress Jingu in northern part of Kyushu such as bathing her newborn baby at Ikiyunomoto-Onsen Hot Spring in Iki City, therefore, it is considered that she had strong associations with this area.

In addition, there are many traditions concerning Empress Jingu in northern part of Kyushu such as bathing her newborn baby at Ikiyunomoto-Onsen Hot Spring in Iki City, therefore, it is considered that she had strong associations with this area.

sen.j: 神功皇后が三韓征伐の後、畿内に帰るとき、自分の皇子（応神天皇）には異母兄にあたる香坂皇子、忍熊皇子が畿内にて反乱を起こして戦いを挑んだが、神功皇后軍は武内宿禰や武振熊命の働きによりこれを平定したという。
sen.e: After "Sankan Seibatsu" (The Conquest of the Three Korean Kingdoms), on the way to Kinai, Kagosaka no miko and Oshikuma no miko, who were brothers by a different mother of his son (Emperor Ojin) rebelled against her and challenged her to fight, however, Empress Jingu's Army suppressed them by work of TAKENOUCHI no Sukune and Takefurukuma no mikoto.

After "Sankan Seibatsu" (The Conquest of the Three Korean Kingdoms), on the way to Kinai, Kagosaka no miko and Oshikuma no miko, who were brothers by a different mother of her son (Emperor Ojin), rebelled against her and challenged her to fight, however, Empress Jingu's Army suppressed them by work of TAKENOUCHI no Sukune and Takefurukuma no mikoto.
sen.cmt: his son をher sonに変更。 rebelledの前にカンマを挿入。
sen.e: After "Sankan Seibatsu" (The Conquest of the Three Korean Kingdoms), on the way to Kinai, Kagosaka no miko and Oshikuma no miko, who were brothers by a different mother of her son (Emperor Ojin), rebelled against her and challenged her to fight, however, Empress Jingu's Army suppressed them by work of TAKENOUCHI no Sukune and Takefurukuma no mikoto.

sen.j: この時代は、長期間にわたって天皇が空位のままだったため、明治時代以前は神功皇后を天皇（皇后の臨朝）とみなし、15代の帝と数えられていたが、1926年（大正15年）10月の詔書により、歴代天皇から外された。
sen.e: Since the post of Emperor had been vacant for a long time in this period, Emperor Jingu was considered to be the Emperor (Empress acted as Emperor) and counted as the fifteenth Emperor, however, she was excluded from successive Emperors by Shosho (imperial edict, decree) issued in October 1926.

Since the post of Emperor had been vacant for a long time in this period, Emperor Jingu was considered to be the Emperor (Empress acted as Emperor) and counted as the fifteenth Emperor, however, she was excluded from successive Emperors by Shosho (imperial edict, decree) issued in October 1926.

Since the post of Emperor had been vacant for a long time in this period, Emperor Jingu was considered to be the Emperor (Empress acted as Emperor) and counted as the fifteenth Emperor, however, she was excluded from successive Emperors by Shosho (imperial edict, decree) issued in October 1926.

sen.j: 明治から太平洋戦争敗戦までは、研究の場では江戸時代より様々な論考があったにもかかわらず、学校教育において実在の人物として教えるよう指導されていた。
sen.e: Although there had been various discussion on Emperor Jingu in the research setting since the Edo period, teachers were directed to teach Emperor Jingu as a real, existing person from Meiji period to Defeat in the Pacific War.

Although there had been various discussions on Empress Jingu in the research setting since the Edo period, teachers were directed to teach that Empress Jingu was a real, existing person from the Meiji period until the defeat in the Pacific War.
sen.cmt: Emperor JinguをEmpress Jinguに変更、その他表現の見直し
sen.e: Although there had been various discussions on Empress Jingu in the research setting since the Edo period, teachers were directed to teach that Empress Jingu was a real, existing person from the Meiji period until the defeat in the Pacific War.

sen.j: 現在では実在説と非実在説が並存している。
sen.e: Today, theory of her existence and theory of her nonexistence exist together.
Today, theory of her existence and theory of her nonexistence exist together.
Today, theory of her existence and theory of her nonexistence exist together.

sen.j: 日本書紀において 巻九に神功皇后摂政「66年 是年 晋武帝泰初二年晉起居注云 武帝泰初（泰始）二年十月 倭女王遣重貢獻」と中国と倭の女王の記述が引用されており、収録するにあたってヤマト王権と「卑弥呼」を関連づけさせる為に伝承が作り上げられたという説がある。
sen.e: In volume 9 of "Nihonshoki", the description of Princess of China and Princess of Wa (Japan) "According to a record keeper of Jjin Dynasty of China, the Empress of Japan paid a tribute to the Emperor Wu of Jin Dynasty on October, 266" was quoted and there is a theory that the tradition was made up in order to link "Himiko (first known ruler of Japan)" with Yamato dynasty/Yamato (Imperial) Court, before editing.
sen.cmt: 日本語の意味が理解できなかったため、Webを確認したところ、大幅に異なる内容が書いてありました。この通りに訳しましたが・・・。
sen.e: In volume 9 of Nihonshoki, the description on Princess of China and Princess of Wa (Japan) "According to a record keeper of Jjin Dynasty of China, the Empress of Japan paid a tribute to the Emperor Wu of Jin Dynasty on October, 266" was quoted; and there is a theory that the tradition was made up in order to link "Himiko" (first known ruler of Japan) with Yamato dynasty/Yamato (Imperial) Court, in editing the document.
sen.cmt: Nihonshokiについている引用符を削除。was quotedの次にセミコロン（;）を挿入。before editingをin editing the documentに変更。
sen.e: In volume 9 of Nihonshoki, the description on Princess of China and Princess of Wa (Japan) "According to a record keeper of Jjin Dynasty of China, the Empress of Japan paid a tribute to the Emperor Wu of Jin Dynasty on October, 266" was quoted; and there is a theory that the tradition was made up in order to link "Himiko" (first known ruler of Japan) with Yamato dynasty/Yamato (Imperial) Court, in editing the document.

sen.j: 直木孝次郎は皇極天皇と持統天皇がモデルではないかとの説を唱えている。
sen.e: Kojiro NAOKI advocated the theory that she was modeled after Empress Kogyoku and Empress Jito.
Kojiro NAOKI advocated the theory that she was modeled after Empress Kogyoku and Empress Jito.
Kojiro NAOKI advocated the theory that she was modeled after Empress Kogyoku and Empress Jito.

sen.j: 卑弥呼と同じような巫女王とする見方もある。
sen.e: There is also a view that she is a shaman princess same as Himiko.
There is also a view that she was a shaman princess same as Himiko.
sen.cmt: she is を she wasに変更
sen.e: There is also a view that she was a shaman princess same as Himiko.

sen.j: 住吉三神とともに住吉大神の1柱として、また応神天皇とともに八幡神の1柱として信仰されるようになる。
sen.e: She became to be worshiped as not only one of Sumiyoshi Okami with Sumiyoshi Sanjin (Sumiyoshi three deities) but also one of the Hachimanjin (the god of Hachiman-gu Shrine)
She became to be worshiped as not only one of Sumiyoshi Okami with Sumiyoshi Sanjin (Sumiyoshi three deities) but also one of the Hachimanjin (the god of Hachiman-gu Shrine).
sen.cmt: 最後にピリオドを追加
sen.e: She became to be worshiped as not only one of Sumiyoshi Okami with Sumiyoshi Sanjin (Sumiyoshi three deities) but also one of the Hachimanjin (the god of Hachiman-gu Shrine).

sen.j: 大分県の宇佐神宮、大阪府大阪市の住吉大社をはじめ、福岡県福津市の宮地嶽神社、福岡県大川市の風浪宮など、いくつかの神社の祭神となっている。
sen.e: She also became an enshrined deity of several shrines such as Usa-jingu Shrine in Oita Prefecture, Sumiyoshitaisha Shrine in Osaka City, Osaka Prefecture, Miyajidake-jinja Shrine in Fukutus City, Fukuoka Prefecture and Furogu Shrine in Okawa City, Fukuoka Prefecture.

She also became an enshrined deity of several shrines such as Usa-jingu Shrine in Oita Prefecture, Sumiyoshitaisha Shrine in Osaka City, Osaka Prefecture, Miyajidake-jinja Shrine in Fukutus City, Fukuoka Prefecture and Furogu Shrine in Okawa City, Fukuoka Prefecture.

She also became an enshrined deity of several shrines such as Usa-jingu Shrine in Oita Prefecture, Sumiyoshitaisha Shrine in Osaka City, Osaka Prefecture, Miyajidake-jinja Shrine in Fukutus City, Fukuoka Prefecture and Furogu Shrine in Okawa City, Fukuoka Prefecture.

sen.j: 所縁ある福岡市の香椎宮や筥崎宮、福岡県宇美町の宇美八幡宮、壱岐市の聖母宮でも祀られている。
sen.e: She was also enshrined in Kashii-gu Shrine and Hakozakigu Shrine in Fukuoka City where she had close ties to, Umi-hachimangu Shrine in Umi cho Fukuoka Prefecture, and Seibo-gu Shrine in Iki City.
She was also enshrined in Kashii-gu Shrine and Hakozakigu Shrine in Fukuoka City where she had close ties to, Umi-hachimangu Shrine in Umi cho Fukuoka Prefecture, and Seibo-gu Shrine in Iki City.
She was also enshrined in Kashii-gu Shrine and Hakozakigu Shrine in Fukuoka City where she had close ties to, Umi-hachimangu Shrine in Umi cho Fukuoka Prefecture, and Seibo-gu Shrine in Iki City.

sen.j: 宮内庁では、奈良市にある五社神古墳を神功皇后陵（狭城楯列池上陵）としている。
sen.e: Imperial Household Agency officially designated Gozashi-kofun Tomb as Mausoleum of Empress Jingu (Sasatatanamiike no e no misasagi).
Imperial Household Agency officially designated Gozashi-kofun Tomb as Mausoleum of Empress Jingu (Sasatatanamiike no e no misasagi).
Imperial Household Agency officially designated Gozashi-kofun Tomb as Mausoleum of Empress Jingu (Sasatatanamiike no e no misasagi).

sen.j: 神功皇后の陵墓については、古事記では「御陵在沙紀之盾列池上陵（御陵は沙紀の盾列池上陵（さきのたたなみのいけがみのみささぎ）に在り）」、日本書紀では「葬狭城盾列陵（狭城盾列陵（さきのたたなみのみささぎ）に葬る）」と記している。
sen.e: Concerning Mausoleum of Empress Jingu, there is a description that "her mausoleum is located in Sakinotatanami no e ikegami no misasagi" in "Kojiki", while there is a description that "she was buried in Sakinotatanami no misasagi" in "Nihonshoki."

Concerning Mausoleum of Empress Jingu, there is a description that "her mausoleum is located in Sakinotatanami no e ikegami no misasagi" in Kojiki, while there is a description that "she was buried in Sakinotatanami no misasagi" in Nihonshoki.
sen.cmt: KojikiおよびNihonshokiに付いている引用符を削除
sen.e: Concerning Mausoleum of Empress Jingu, there is a description that "her mausoleum is located in Sakinotatanami no e ikegami no misasagi" in Kojiki, while there is a description that "she was buried in Sakinotatanami no misasagi" in Nihonshoki.

sen.j: 狭城盾列陵とは佐紀盾列古墳群のことである。
sen.e: Sakinotatanami no misasagi is Sakitatenami Burial Mounds.
Sakinotatanami no misasagi is Sakitatenami Burial Mounds.
Sakinotatanami no misasagi is Sakitatenami Burial Mounds.

sen.j: 承和 (日本)10年（843年）、盾列陵で奇異があり、調査の結果、神功皇后陵と成務天皇陵を混同していたことがわかったという記事が『続日本後紀』にある。
sen.e: In 843, there is a story in "Shoku Nihon Koki" (Later Chronicle of Japan Continued) that the study of mausoleum conducted after strange thing happened at tatanami no misasagi revealed that Mausoleum of Empress Jingu was confounded with Mausoleum of Emperor Seimu.

There is a story in "Shoku Nihon Koki" (Later Chronicle of Japan Continued) that investigation into a strange matter at the tatanami no misasagi revealed in 843 that Mausoleum of Empress Jingu was confounded with Mausoleum of Emperor Seimu.

There is a story in "Shoku Nihon Koki" (Later Chronicle of Japan Continued) that investigation into a strange matter at the tatanami no misasagi revealed in 843 that Mausoleum of Empress Jingu was confounded with Mausoleum of Emperor Seimu.

sen.j: 後に、「御陵山」と呼ばれていた佐紀盾列古墳群主な古墳（現 日葉酢媛命陵）が神功皇后陵とみなされるようになり、神功皇后の神話での事績から安産祈願に霊験ありとして多くの人が参拝していた。
sen.e: Later, Sakitatenami Burial Mounds (present Hibasuhime no mikoto ryo (The mausoleum of Princess Hibasu)) which had been called "Omihaka yama" was considered to be Mausoleum of Empress Jingu, and many people visited this place where served as wonder-working deity for a safe birth according achievements of Empress Jingu in myth.
sen.cmt: 原文を確認したところ、一行目の”主な古墳”は、不要と思われ、また、この通りに訳すことは困難なので、はずして訳しました。
sen.e: Later, Sakitatenami Burial Mounds (present Hibasuhime no mikoto ryo (The mausoleum of Princess Hibasu)) which had been called "Omihaka yama" was considered to be Mausoleum of Empress Jingu, and many people visited this place where served as wonder-working deity for a safe birth according achievements of Empress Jingu in myth.

Later, Sakitatenami Burial Mounds (present Hibasuhime no mikoto ryo (The mausoleum of Princess Hibasu)) which had been called "Omihaka yama" was considered to be Mausoleum of Empress Jingu, and many people visited this place where served as wonder-working deity for a safe birth according achievements of Empress Jingu in myth.

sen.j: その後、西大寺 (奈良市)で「京北班田図」が発見され、これにより神功皇后陵が現在地であることが判明し、文久3年（1863年）、五社神古墳が神功皇后陵に治定された。
sen.e: After that, with the discovery of "Keihoku Handen zu (the map of Keihoku Jori area)", it turned out that the present place was Mausoleum of Empress Jingu, and Gozashi-kofun Tomb was authorized as her Mausoleum.

After that, with the discovery of "Keihoku Handen zu" (the map of Keihoku Jori area), it turned out that the present place was Mausoleum of Empress Jingu; Gozashi-kofun Tomb was authorized as her mausoleum in 1863.
sen.cmt: in 1863 を追加。途中にセミコロン(;)を追加。
sen.e: After that, with the discovery of "Keihoku Handen zu" (the map of Keihoku Jori area), it turned out that the present place was Mausoleum of Empress Jingu; Gozashi-kofun Tomb was authorized as her mausoleum in 1863.

sen.j: かつて、明治時代の改造紙幣にその肖像が用いられ、これが日本における最初の女性肖像紙幣となったが、その原版はイタリア人技術者エドアルド・キヨッソーネが作成したため、西洋風の美人に描かれている。
sen.e: Once, portrait of Empress Jingu was used for banknote in Meiji period and she became the first Japanese woman to be featured on the Japanese banknote, however since its original version was made by Italian engineer, Edoardo Chiossone, she was portrayed as beautiful woman in western style.

The portrait of Empress Jingu was used for a banknote in the Meiji period and she became the first Japanese woman to be featured on the Japanese banknote, however since its original version was made by an Italian engineer, Edoardo Chiossone, she was portrayed as a beautiful woman in western style.

The portrait of Empress Jingu was used for a banknote in the Meiji period and she became the first Japanese woman to be featured on the Japanese banknote, however since its original version was made by an Italian engineer, Edoardo Chiossone, she was portrayed as a beautiful woman in western style.

sen.j: なお、中央銀行たる日本銀行発足以前の事であるためこの紙幣は日本銀行券ではなく、不換紙幣の「政府紙幣」であった。
sen.e: This banknote was issued before the establishment of Central Bank, the Bank of Japan, therefore this was not Bank of Japan note but inconvertible paper currency, "government note".
This banknote was issued before the establishment of Central Bank, the Bank of Japan, therefore this was not Bank of Japan note but inconvertible paper currency, "government note."
sen.cmt: ピリオドを右引用符の内側に移動
sen.e: This banknote was issued before the establishment of Central Bank, the Bank of Japan, therefore this was not Bank of Japan note but inconvertible paper currency, "government note."
